    (i) State what it means for surfaces f:U→R3f: U \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{3}f:U→R3 and g:V→R3g: V \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{3}g:V→R3 to be isometric.

    Let f:U→R3f: U \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{3}f:U→R3 be a surface, ϕ:V→U\phi: V \rightarrow Uϕ:V→U a diffeomorphism, and let g=f∘ϕ:V→g=f \circ \phi: V \rightarrowg=f∘ϕ:V→ R3.\mathbb{R}^{3} .R3.

    State a formula comparing the first fundamental forms of fff and ggg.

    (ii) Give a proof of the formula referred to at the end of part (i). Deduce that "isometry" is an equivalence relation.

    The catenoid and the helicoid are the surfaces defined by

    (u,v)→(ucos⁡v,usin⁡v,v)(u, v) \rightarrow(u \cos v, u \sin v, v) (u,v)→(ucosv,usinv,v)

    and

    (ϑ,z)→(cosh⁡zcos⁡ϑ,cosh⁡zsin⁡ϑ,z)(\vartheta, z) \rightarrow(\cosh z \cos \vartheta, \cosh z \sin \vartheta, z) (ϑ,z)→(coshzcosϑ,coshzsinϑ,z)

    Show that the catenoid and the helicoid are isometric.

    X7+1=(X+1)(X3+X+1)(X3+X2+1)X^{7}+1=(X+1)\left(X^{3}+X+1\right)\left(X^{3}+X^{2}+1\right) X7+1=(X+1)(X3+X+1)(X3+X2+1)

    in F2[X]\mathbb{F}_{2}[X]F2​[X], find all cyclic binary codes of length 7 . Identify those which are Hamming codes and their duals. Justify your answer.

    (i) Consider the unconstrained geometric programme GP

     minimise g(t)=∑i=1nci∏j=1mtjaij\text { minimise } g(t)=\sum_{i=1}^{n} c_{i} \prod_{j=1}^{m} t_{j}^{a_{i j}}  minimise g(t)=i=1∑n​ci​j=1∏m​tjaij​​

    subject to tj>0j=1,…,mt_{j}>0 \quad j=1, \ldots, mtj​>0j=1,…,m.

    State the dual problem to GP. Give a careful statement of the AM-GM inequality, and use it to prove the primal-dual inequality for GP.

    (ii) Define min-path and max-tension problems. State and outline the proof of the max-tension min-path theorem.

    A company has branches in five cities A,B,C,DA, B, C, DA,B,C,D and EEE. The fares for direct flights between these cities are as follows:

    \begin{tabular}{l|lllll} & A\mathrm{A}A & B\mathrm{B}B & C\mathrm{C}C & D\mathrm{D}D & E\mathrm{E}E \ \hline A\mathrm{A}A & −-− & 50 & 40 & 25 & 10 \  B\mathrm{~B} B & 50 & −-− & 20 & 90 & 25 \ C\mathrm{C}C & 40 & 20 & −-− & 10 & 25 \ D\mathrm{D}D & 25 & 90 & 10 & −-− & 55 \ E\mathrm{E}E & 10 & 25 & 25 & 55 & −-− \end{tabular}

    Formulate this as a min-path problem. Illustrate the max-tension min-path algorithm by finding the cost of travelling by the cheapest routes between DDD and each of the other cities.
